title: unban my account please.
body:

> can't be responsible for something i had no idea was gonna happen.

You are responsible for your account's security - that means that **you should not let _any_ other person access your account, _period_.** It doesn't matter if you don't know whether or not they'd use hacks, **you're not supposed to let them play on your account period.**

If they want to play League, it's a **Free-to-Play** game. They can make and ruin their own account. But your account is your responsibility, so when you let someone else play on your account, what they do on it _is your responsibility._

> of course he had his fun and i get punished doesn't sound right to me.

Well, for one, as above, what happens on your account is entirely your responsibility. If you let someone else play on your account, you're responsible for their behavior, whether they flame, intentionally feed, cheat, or whatever else.

Beyond that, account sharing is in and of itself punishable by a permanent account suspension. Because, also as stated above; _**you're the only person who should be playing on your account.**_

> ive spend alot of money on that account and would like it back. that all.

You spent a lot of money in **_non-refundable transactions._** All of the money you spent on that account was forfeit when you (both directly and by proxy of your nephew) broke the rules and merited a permanent suspension. You're not going to be able to get the money back, as per the [Terms of Use](https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/legal/termsofuse#account-termination).

People already try to come up with excuses to try to justify their behavior when they're punished, and saying "It wasn't me, it was someone else" is just an easy way out of accountability. There's also the issue of leaderboard and matchmaking integrity-Jack's account could be in the top 10 of the leaderboard or have an MMR comparable to that of Gold ranked players, but it wasn't actually Jack who played on the account, but instead Jill. He didn't get to there legitimately, he had someone else do the work for him. which also means that his antics prevented legitimate contenders from reaching that status.

I could go on but there are many good answers provided [here](https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/questions/148354/why-is-account-sharing-so-bad) about why account sharing is against the rules that explain it better than I can.

Perhaps in the grand scheme of things they are, but for competitions that try to be legitimate and fair those rankings do hold meaning. For example, speedrunning is a popular form of competition, yet there have been people who have violated the integrity of it by falsifying their records (TASing, splicing separate runs together to make it appear legitimate, etc.), which has led to those individuals being banned from the games in question.

There's also the matter of Esports titles. Many teams look to the rankings to see who has the potential to become a pro, and that process can become compromised if it turns out the person they had their eye on cheated to get there, which in turn can make legitimately skilled players go unnoticed for longer than they would otherwise.

Of course for a normally free to play game this may not seem to big a deal, but for competitions with cash prizes it is, as the 1st place player who cheated to win is preventing the non-cheaters from winning and getting their accurate placements/prizes if that makes sense.

It is why speedruns are verified before being declared. And why teams do tests. Also cheating on a tournament and playing a few ranked games on someone elses account are not in the same scope. You can ban one but still not ban the other you know?

I addressed this part: people have been known to post runs that to the untrained eye are perfectly valid but in reality are false and only got verified because they did a good enough job making it look legit, with some of them only being discovered to be false months or years after they were posted.

>And why teams do tests. Also cheating on a tournament and playing a few ranked games on someone elses account are not in the same scope. You can ban one but still not ban the other you know?

The bottom line is that account sharing causes more harm than good, and people are responsible for any and all actions taken on their accounts. If Jack lets Jill play on his account despite knowing the potential consequences and Jill ends up behaving in a way that axes the account then Jack has to be held responsible for letting Jill use his own account in the first place. Sure Jack may not normally behave like Jill does but how is anyone else supposed to know that outside of them? If Jill truly wanted to play the game then she would just make her own account rather than using someone else to do so. This way both people can play at the same time, and if Jill happens to get in trouble and loses her account because of it, Jack will still be able to play on his account despite that, risk, guilt and consequence free.

And sure account compromises can happen most definitely, but more often than not it's someone willingly letting someone else have access to their account and any personal information on that account.

You are free to disagree that account sharing is bad but that's just how it is.

Even if you didn't know he was going to use hacks, account sharing by itself is against the rules and everything that's done under your name is ultimately your responsibility.
